conclusion: Shadows are influenced by the position of the light source, the height of the objects, and the relative distances between the objects and the light source.
The light source is currently positioned above the objects, and the shadows A, B, C, and D are cast on the ground.

Each shadow corresponds to a specific object: A is the shadow of the lamp-like object, B is the shadow of the vertical cookie, C is the shadow of the cake, and D is the shadow of the ice cream with a cherry on top.
When the light source moves forward, shadows will shift backward because the direction of the shadow is always opposite to the light source.
The farther the object is from the light source, the more its shadow will shift.
Shadows will generally become longer because the light source is moving farther away from the objects horizontally.
Taller objects will have more noticeable elongation compared to shorter objects.
The lamp's shadow will shift backward slightly and elongate a little, but the change will not be as dramatic as for taller objects.
The cookie's shadow will shift backward significantly and elongate noticeably.
The cake's shadow will shift backward slightly and elongate a little, similar to the lamp.
The ice cream's shadow will shift backward significantly and elongate noticeably, similar to the cookie.
All shadows will shift backward when the light source moves forward above the objects.
Shadows of taller objects will become longer and more noticeable.
Shadows of shorter objects will also elongate but to a lesser extent.
